name: Context-Aware Sensor Alert Management
description: This use case enables personalized management of wearable sensor alerts for older adults with varying privacy preferences and caregiver roles, ensuring critical health data is shared appropriately while minimizing non-essential notifications during caregivers' busy periods.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker, has always been wary of technology and protective of her privacy. When her informal caregiver Sarah Thompson suggests using ALFRED to help monitor her health through wearable sensors, Olivia’s first reaction is distrust. She insists that the device only share minimal data, strictly limiting any alerts to emergency situations, and refuses the idea of video check-ins, preferring offline updates. Olivia’s voice is firm when she tells ALFRED to “push-to-talk” only when she initiates, shutting down nearly all unsolicited notifications. For her, ALFRED must be a silent guardian, quietly tracking vital signs without overwhelming her or sharing data beyond her strict boundaries.

Meanwhile, Sarah, juggling care for multiple clients including Olivia, thrives on constant connectivity. She has configured her ALFRED interface to accept all notifications immediately, wanting to stay responsive at any hour. Sarah enjoys engaging with clients through ALFRED’s interactive features, often encouraging Olivia to participate in light games or chats to lift her spirits, though Olivia resists. Sarah finds herself caught between respecting Olivia’s desire for formality and privacy, and her own instinct to foster emotional bonds through the technology. She manually manages the logging of information, wary of automatic recordings that could complicate her multitasking routine across clients.

On the other hand, Mike Johnson, the registered nurse overseeing Olivia’s medical care during his busy urban shifts, demands a streamlined experience. He sets ALFRED to block all non-critical notifications during work hours, wanting only urgent alerts that require immediate attention. Mike appreciates quick, validated access to Olivia’s vital data without distractions, and becomes frustrated when the system’s privacy restrictions slow down his ability to review her health trends. He rarely interacts with ALFRED outside of official hours, and firmly avoids any non-clinical features, dismissing Sarah’s enthusiasm for games as unnecessary noise.

The result is a push-and-pull dynamic: Olivia’s cautious control over data sharing clashes with Sarah’s desire for open communication and emotional connection, while Mike’s strict clinical focus demands critical alerts only, sidelining both Olivia’s and Sarah’s preferences. ALFRED must navigate this tense balance, delivering tailored sensor alerts that respect Olivia’s privacy, keep Sarah thoroughly informed, and remain unobtrusive enough for Mike’s high-pressure workflow. Despite the conflicts, the system manages to prevent missed emergencies and supports Olivia’s care, even as each persona wrestles with their differing expectations and comfort levels with technology.
